com.samsung.android.sdk.healthdata

Class HealthData

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.samsung.android.sdk.healthdata.HealthData
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Parcelable

    public final class HealthData
extends Object
implements Parcelable
    This class presents an object for a health data type, e.g., the blood pressure or weight. Quantitative and qualitative values can be specified for the specific health data type based on its data structure definition. It is used to manage health data with HealthDataResolver.

    You can use predefined data types or create your own data types. The HealthData object basically provides the following information.

    • Source device that manages health data
    • Key and value map for structured data properties of the data type

    Predefined Data Types

    The Health data framework provides predefined data types. If predefined data types are enough for your application, use them without new data type definition. Refer to HealthConstants for detailed information.

    Custom Health Data Types

    The Health data framework also supports defining custom health data types. It follows the FQDN (fully qualified domain name) style for the health data type name. Define the name of your custom data type using the same style to avoid the name collision. If you check the data type name of HealthConstants.BloodGlucose, you can find its value as below.

      E.g., "com.samsung.health.blood_glucose"

    The custom health data type can be defined with all new properties depending on the design of your application or existing predefined data types in the platform. The following common properties needs to be defined for the custom data type.

    • "datauuid" (text): the unique ID of health data. It's assigned by the system.
    • "create_time" (long): the created time of health data. It's assigned by the system.
    • "update_time" (long): the updated time of health data. It's assigned by the system.
    • "pkg_name" (text): the application package name that provides health data. It's assigned by the system.
    • "deviceuuid" (text): device identifier. Set it with setSourceDevice(String)

    The defined custom data type needs to be registered on the related site. Refer to Programming Guide in the [health-sdk]/Docs.

    Health data can be inserted and checked as below. 

    import android.util.Log;
import android.database.Cursor;
import com.samsung.android.sdk.healthdata.*;

public class HealthDataExample {

    // The state of connection
    private HealthDataStore mStore;

    private void insertGlucose(long start, long offset, float value) {

        HealthDevice myDevice = new HealthDeviceManager(mStore).getLocalDevice();
        HealthData data = new HealthData();
        data.setSourceDevice(myDevice.getUuid());

        // Fills all mandatory properties out
        data.putLong(HealthConstants.BloodGlucose.START_TIME, start);
        data.putLong(HealthConstants.BloodGlucose.TIME_OFFSET, offset);
        data.putFloat(HealthConstants.BloodGlucose.GLUCOSE, value);
        data.putInt(HealthConstants.BloodGlucose.MEASUREMENT_TYPE,
            HealthConstants.BloodGlucose.MEASUREMENT_TYPE_WHOLE_BLOOD);

        HealthDataResolver resolver = new HealthDataResolver(mStore, null);
        HealthDataResolver.InsertRequest insRequest = new HealthDataResolver.InsertRequest.Builder()
            .setDataType(HealthConstants.BloodGlucose.HEALTH_DATA_TYPE)
            .build();

        // Adds health data
        insRequest.addHealthData(data);
        try {
            resolver.insert(insRequest);
        } catch (Exception e) {
            Log.d(APP_TAG, "resolver.insert() fails.");
        }

        HealthDataResolver.ReadRequest rdRequest = new HealthDataResolver.ReadRequest.Builder()
            .setDataType(HealthConstants.BloodGlucose.HEALTH_DATA_TYPE)
            .build();

        // Reads health data
        try {
            resolver.read(rdRequest).setResultListener(mRdListener);
        } catch (Exception e) {
            Log.d(APP_TAG, "resolver.read() fails.");
        }
    }

    private final HealthResultHolder.ResultListener<HealthDataResolver.ReadResult> mRdListener =
        new HealthResultHolder.ResultListener<HealthDataResolver.ReadResult>() {

        @Override
        public void onResult(HealthDataResolver.ReadResult result) {
            // Checks the result
            Cursor c = result.getResultCursor();
       }
    };
}

        public String getUuid()

        Returns:
        The ID of the source device which provides health data

      • setSourceDevice

        public void setSourceDevice(String deviceUuid)
        Sets the source device which provides health data. It's mandatory to set the source device for created health data.
        Parameters:
        deviceUuid - The source device ID which provides health data

      • getString

        public String getString(String key)
        Gets a text value associated with a given property.
        Parameters:
        key - The specific property name of health data that its value type is text.
          E.g., HealthConstants.Exercise.COMMENT
        Returns:
        The text value,
        or null if the health data object does not have the given property

        or 0.0f if the health data object does not have the given property
